tags: if only i could put this much effort into my school work
but then i wouldnt relate to these two anymore
theyre so dumb i love them
summary: there’s a post somewhere that says aziraphel and crowley never actually accomplish anything and i’ve been thinking about it a...
body: there’s a post somewhere that says aziraphel and crowley never actually accomplish anything and i’ve been thinking about it a lot because of how true it is. and i can’t help but think that it’s more than them just cancelling each other out. rather, it’s them literally procrastinating stopping armageddon until literally seconds before it happens. the line “come up with something or else i’ll never speak to you again” was spoken literally as the devil was ripping through the earth and they literally did not have a plan (except for killing adam, which neither of them fully agreed to) until they realized neither gabriel or beelzebub knew anything about the supposed great plan. these dumbass husbands had 11 years to think of something better than cancelling out each other’s influences. and when they realized they had the wrong kid, they still had a week to figure something out and for like 6 days they did nothing but bicker and come up with escape plans and not communicate. this is the dumbass representation i’ve been waiting for.

summary: Aziraphale had learned a dance called the Gavotte in a discreet gentlemen’s club in Portland Place in the late 1880s. After a...
caption:
Aziraphale had learned a dance called the Gavotte in a discreet gentlemen’s club in Portland Place in the late 1880s. After a while, he had become fairly good at it and was quite put out when, some decades later, the Gavotte went out of style for good.

someone in the tags made me realise that i forgot the absolute most relevant smile

title: Michael Sheen - South Bank Show
excerpt: This video is about Michael Sheen - South Bank Show
description:
“My instinct is always toward characters who are outside the norm in some way. Possibly transgressive in some way, but certainly display very unacceptable qualities for some reason. For instance, I did a thing call Dirty Filthy Love about a guy with turrets and OCD. I played two emperors: Caligula and Nero. Now, on the one hand, I’m drawn to those characters because they’re a challenge because it pushes you as an actor. But mainly because I have no interest in playing evil, you know. It’s a sort of a pantomime concept to me. What I’m interested in playing are human beings who, as an audience, you see doing monstrous things, and you don’t apologize for it, you don’t do special pleading for it. But you allow an audience- find a way for an audience to empathize with them because when drama first was created or sprung out of the unconscious, it was, I believe, a way for a community to come together and feel like they belonged, to be included. These are the things that are important to us. These are the things that bind us together. So, if I can take characters, play characters who are displaying qualities that, on the whole, we as a society try and keep- don’t want to accept, it allows us to accept our own unacceptable things that we’re told are unacceptable about ourselves, and then slowly we all come back together again as a society again, I think.” 

-Michael Sheen on South Bank Show (2007)

For instance, I did a thing call Dirty Filthy Love about a guy with turrets and OCD. I played two emperors: Caligula and Nero. Now, on the one hand, I’m drawn to those characters because they’re a challenge because it pushes you as an actor. But mainly because I have no interest in playing evil, you know. It’s a sort of a pantomime concept to me. What I’m interested in playing are human beings who, as an audience, you see doing monstrous things, and you don’t apologize for it, you don’t do special pleading for it. But you allow an audience- find a way for an audience to empathize with them because when drama first was created or sprung out of the unconscious, it was, I believe, a way for a community to come together and feel like they belonged, to be included. These are the things that are important to us. These are the things that bind us together. So, if I can take characters, play characters who are displaying qualities that, on the whole, we as a society try and keep- don’t want to accept, it allows us to accept our own unacceptable things that we’re told are unacceptable about ourselves, and then slowly we all come back together again as a society again, I think.”

title: Michael Sheen on Bake Off?
body: Has anyone got a copy of the charity Bake Off Michael Sheen was part of in 2015? The other bakers were Jameela Jamil, David Mitchell, and Sarah Brown.  YouTube took it down, and I really want to watch it again….

summary: michael sheen moves his body in an entirely different way when he’s crowley-as-aziraphale and it fucks me up. usually,...
body: michael sheen moves his body in an entirely different way when he’s crowley-as-aziraphale and it fucks me up. usually, aziraphale walks with his shoulders back, because he’s so damn rigid. but when it’s crowley-as-aziraphale, he moves with his shoulders forward. which is actually how crowley moves, it’s part of his saunter, because he’s always slouching, and slouching pushes your shoulders forward. of course, crowley is trying to carry himself like aziraphale, so most of his posture is different, but his shoulders are forward. watch the bit where he walks through the bookshop, and you can see it. it’s such a small artifact of crowley’s character, but I love it. I love the nuance that michael sheen put into crowley-as-aziraphale.

I love the nuance that michael sheen put into crowley-as-aziraphale.

I love the nuance that michael sheen put into crowley-as-aziraphale.
